subject: Re: [junit] TDD Using NetBeans 6.5+ and JUnit.

messageBody:
Karl,

Eclipse also has a UI feature that will automatically create a JUnit
test case class from an existing class. I never use it. Instead, I
manually create test classes. Does NetBeans make this more difficult?

David Saff

On Sun, Apr 19, 2009 at 6:18 PM, Karl Krasnowsky <karlkras@...> wrote:
> This question is really targeted to those who have used Kent Beck's book, Test-Driven Development within the context of the NetBeans IDE, otherwise please disregard.
>
> Maybe someone here can provide a pointer to already available information on this.
> I'm using Kent Beck's book, Test-Driven Development as a tutorial and was looking at how i might use NetBeans with its JUnit plugin to mimic his recommended processes, but right out of the gate I'm having a fundamental issue.
> A standard practice of KB's method is to code the test before any code is written, and then backfill the empty bits (class, methods, variables, etc.) to make the test work.
> for example, here's the first JUnit test he shows in chapter 1 to begin building from:
> Code:
>    public void testMultiplication() {
>        Dollar five = new Dollar(5);
>        five.times(2);
>        assertEquals(10, five.amount);
>    }
>
> Problem I'm having is, if I'm creating tests out of the context of the Java project, tests in NB aren't created until you have a class with runtime methods to create tests from. So I have a chicken egg sort of situation. NB would do the obvious thing, i.e., have tests generated from code, so the above doesn't make any sense as it implies that the code is generated from the test, which is a cool idea of the IDE could support it.
> I have experience using JUnit, so the framework itself isn't in question, but how to apply this methodology within the IDE format is.
> Do I have to simply short-circuit the default process that NB and the JUnit plugin manufacture?
>
> thanks in advance for any help on this,
> Karl
